awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Integrating Physical Computing and Data Science in Movement Based Learning
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will examine how to integrate machine learning, data science, and physical computing in the context of movement based learning. The project focuses on learning environment design for female high school students who participate in physical education activities such as dance in New York and Colorado. Many of these learners are African American and Latina, populations that are underrepresented in Science, Technology, Engineering and Math (STEM). Researchers will leverage learners' expertise and cultural practices in order to engage them in authentic and personally meaningful computing. The students will learn to create computing systems with programmable electronics worn on the body (physical computing), use those systems to create statistical models of movement and gesture (data science and machine learning), and then apply the models in a digital experiential learning environment. Researchers will work closely with physical education teachers and learners to produce design principles, curricula, new educational technologies, and comparative analyses across contexts. This project is funded by the STEM+Computing (STEM+C) program that supports research and development to understand the integration of computing and computational thinking in STEM learning.

Research questions addressed in this project include: 1) How can physical education be leveraged to build expertise in computing? 2) What are the challenges of integrating computing into physical education practices? and 3) How can we meaningfully assess learning outcomes and dispositional shifts with respect to computing in the context of physical education applications? The research has three phases. Phase I will consist of conducting interviews and observations at three development sites including the non-profit organization STEM From Dance in NYC and two teams in Boulder, Colorado. Phase II will consist of participatory design sessions with physical educators and computing educators to develop a deeper understanding of how physical movement and computing (across the sub-disciplines of machine learning, data science, and physical computing) can complement one another using co-designed physical and computing learning activities. The participatory design and co-design activities will explore how sensing technologies and embodiment affordances can reshape computing education and provide alternative pathways for conceptualizing knowledge and cultivating expertise. Phase III will consist of piloting the integrated physical education and computing curricula across the three sites in NYC and Boulder. The curricula will consist of four 5-week computing modules that will be iterated on within the three development sites. Three of the modules will focus on each of the computing sub-disciplines individually, and the fourth will involve advanced topics integrating the disciplines together. This research will produce curriculum and technology to support learning modules in machine learning, data science, and, physical computing, integrating multiple levels of abstraction across the boundaries of hardware and software (i.e., cyber-physical systems). Through this collaborative inquiry researchers will develop transformative knowledge about how to embed computing into established movement based learning practices, resulting in computing curricula and tools that build on the learners' and educators' authentic practices and needs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Creative computing learning experiences integrate programming and engineering with various arts disciplines, providing new ways for learners to develop skills across the disciplines. Our grant, Integrating Physical Computing and Data Science in Movement Based Learning, aimed to expand the scope and relevance of creative computing by collaborating with community partners in dance and cheerleading, to understand how physical movement, athleticism, and performance could contribute to computational creation. Advancement in affordable electronic sensing technology and computer vision models, have made it possible for learners to program around movement-based data as part of artistic and athletic practices; however, little was known about how these should be leveraged within educational experiences to expand learning and participation in computing. Two major challenges are: (1) providing interfaces for learners to access and leverage data about their body positions and movements in a way that supports their creativity and dance practices while learning to program, and (2) supporting quick and easy construction of wearable electronics that can be programmed to create synergistic relationships between the sensing and outputs within a composition. We investigated these challenges working with the organization STEM from Dance, who expands STEM opportunities for girls of color across the US and a set of cheer teams in Colorado. 

Through collaborative design research we developed and studied two open-source technology innovations. The first is danceON, which enables learners to code animations that are responsive to the body's position and movement. The system integrates a machine learning (ML) pose detection and classification model that provides the learner access to key body positions within a pixel grid of every frame of a video within their code. Learners can then draw environmental animations, such as rain falling from the sky, as well as animations that are bound to the body, such as lasers shooting from the wrists. Additionally, learners can code the animations to trigger based on conditionals they map to their various movements; for example, having the rain trigger when they clap their hands above their head. We found that the tool engages learners in mathematical, logical, and computational thinking as they develop their code and the necessary calculations to sense particular body movements within the video. 

The second technology we developed was DanceBits. It’s a plug-and-play electronics toolkit that supports rapid design and development of programmable wearables. The kit consists of a programmable microcontroller, a set of movement sensors, various LED configurations, and jumper wires. All of the components are mounted on electronic boards that we designed to be easily affixed to clothing. We found that the plug-and-play design supported learners’ quick, iterative processes that enabled them to create purposeful computational designs supporting their choreographic choices. The design facilitated learners in exploring the capabilities of the electronics—including how movements were translated into data from these electronic sensors—and how they could leverage this within the decisions they made in the design of their wearables and choreography.

In terms of the intellectual merit, (1) we identified the ways in which sensing and modeling body movement can support learners’ embodied exploration of computational concepts; (2) we found that computational affordances of sensing and modeling the body as part of a creative computing environment can support learners to view it not only as a tool for expressivity but also as a tool for improving their movement practices; (3) we highlighted how performative artistic disciplines can promote youth to develop their identities in relation to computing, but it requires development of a psychologically safe environment and success in the public sharing of learners’ computational artifacts that display their skills; (4) we exposed opportunities for learners to engage in mathematical, visual, and spatial reasoning as they work with computational models of their bodies; (5) we documented hardware design techniques to support learners in rapid construction and iteration of programmable wearable creations that could support movement and performance practices; (6) we identified the ways in which the tools and curricula facilitated coordinated information processing that empower learners to understand the mechanisms of AI and ML embedded in the tools, as well as reflect on the broader impacts these systems; and (7) we have begun expanding these approaches to facilitate more inclusive data science practice and pedagogy with young children and people with cognitive disabilities creating the Data-is-Yours toolkit.

In terms of the broader impacts, the work provided experiences for ~215 youth from historically underrepresented groups in computing and worked with ~15 educators, expanding computing into movement based practices that typically do not involve computing, ML, and data science. We identified the ways educational technologies could develop to create synergistic relationships between the sensing technology, coding environments, and movement practices to support culturally sustaining experiences. By co-developing technology with community partners, we identified how collaborations can redefine how technologies can broaden participation and broaden what learners can do within a computing educational environment.
